Getting Started

Source: vignettes/gettingstarted.Rmd
gettingstarted.Rmd

Basic usage

Let us consider some messy data.frame as a toy example:

library(linelist)
ll_sample <- messy_data()

We can use clean_data() with defaults to let the package to do its best to clean up the data.

clean_data(ll_sample)
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition       messy_dates
#> 1  seclpb    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female           confirmed        2018_10_19
#> 2  frkdua    2018-01-02 12_01_2018 female           suspected        24_12_1989
#> 3  nksrhk    2018-01-06 16_01_2018   male          not_a_case        2018_10_19
#> 4  gclirz    2018-01-03 13_01_2018   male          not_a_case        2018_10_18
#> 5  vmqmfe    2018-01-05 15_01_2018   male           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 6  mgbbvj    2018-01-03 13_01_2018   male          not_a_case        24_12_1989
#> 7  vpdiie    2018-01-06 16_01_2018   male           suspected        2018_10_17
#> 8  nppuez    2018-01-09 19_01_2018 female           confirmed        24_12_1989
#> 9  sywjlz    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 10 enmkfm    2018-01-09 19_01_2018   male           suspected        01_12_2001
#> 11 igdrfl    2018-01-06 16_01_2018 female           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 12 cymvbq    2018-01-11 21_01_2018   male           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#> 13 ixxaui    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female          not_a_case            female
#> 14 uwngba    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female           suspected        2018_10_17
#> 15 toptgn    2018-01-09 19_01_2018   male           suspected              <NA>
#> 16 syqodd    2018-01-11 21_01_2018   male          not_a_case            female
#> 17 obxwgw    2018-01-05 15_01_2018 female            probable        2018_10_18
#> 18 otjnuo    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female          not_a_case        24_12_1989
#> 19 lkdvdq    2018-01-05 15_01_2018   male          not_a_case            female
#> 20 zgvabw    2018-01-07 17_01_2018 female           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#>         lat      lon
#> 1  11.15835 48.63636
#> 2  13.44349 47.70434
#> 3  13.29998 50.40891
#> 4  11.84685 47.10444
#> 5  13.99547 47.11110
#> 6  10.77559 47.80345

#> 17 13.89287 47.09167
#> 18 14.87751 48.76008
#> 19 12.16948 47.89376
#> 20 13.87396 48.38470

Intermediate use

The clean_data() function comes with switches for many of the cleaning capabilities so that you can define a bespoke cleaning process.

clean_data(ll_sample, guess_dates = TRUE, error_tolerance = 0.1)
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition       messy_dates
#> 1  seclpb    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           confirmed        2018_10_19
#> 2  frkdua    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female           suspected        24_12_1989
#> 3  nksrhk    2018-01-06 2018-01-16   male          not_a_case        2018_10_19
#> 4  gclirz    2018-01-03 2018-01-13   male          not_a_case        2018_10_18
#> 5  vmqmfe    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 6  mgbbvj    2018-01-03 2018-01-13   male          not_a_case        24_12_1989
#> 7  vpdiie    2018-01-06 2018-01-16   male           suspected        2018_10_17
#> 8  nppuez    2018-01-09 2018-01-19 female           confirmed        24_12_1989
#> 9  sywjlz    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           suspected        2018_10_18
#> 10 enmkfm    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male           suspected        01_12_2001
#> 11 igdrfl    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female           suspected        2018_10_19
#> 12 cymvbq    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#> 13 ixxaui    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case            female
#> 14 uwngba    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           suspected        2018_10_17
#> 15 toptgn    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male           suspected              <NA>
#> 16 syqodd    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male          not_a_case            female
#> 17 obxwgw    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female            probable        2018_10_18
#> 18 otjnuo    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case        24_12_1989
#> 19 lkdvdq    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male          not_a_case            female
#> 20 zgvabw    2018-01-07 2018-01-17 female           confirmed that_s_24_12_1989
#>         lat      lon
#> 1  11.15835 48.63636
#> 2  13.44349 47.70434
#> 3  13.29998 50.40891
#> 4  11.84685 47.10444
#> 5  13.99547 47.11110
#> 6  10.77559 47.80345
#> 7  11.87493 46.96751
#> 8  15.98660 47.96508
#> 9  14.10095 47.73756
#> 10 16.55314 48.66330
#> 11 13.29012 48.09566
#> 12 12.04832 46.61191
#> 13 15.57623 48.21570
#> 14 10.31869 48.63070
#> 15 13.60474 48.23671
#> 16 12.97878 47.94264
#> 17 13.89287 47.09167
#> 18 14.87751 48.76008
#> 19 12.16948 47.89376
#> 20 13.87396 48.38470

We can prevent the cleaning process from operating on certain columns.

clean_data(ll_sample, guess_dates = TRUE, protect = names(ll_sample) == "messy/dates")
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition
#> 1  seclpb    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           confirmed
#> 2  frkdua    2018-01-02 2018-01-12 female           suspected
#> 3  nksrhk    2018-01-06 2018-01-16   male          not_a_case
#> 4  gclirz    2018-01-03 2018-01-13   male          not_a_case
#> 5  vmqmfe    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male           suspected
#> 6  mgbbvj    2018-01-03 2018-01-13   male          not_a_case
#> 7  vpdiie    2018-01-06 2018-01-16   male           suspected
#> 8  nppuez    2018-01-09 2018-01-19 female           confirmed
#> 9  sywjlz    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female           suspected
#> 10 enmkfm    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male           suspected
#> 11 igdrfl    2018-01-06 2018-01-16 female           suspected
#> 12 cymvbq    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male           confirmed
#> 13 ixxaui    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case
#> 14 uwngba    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female           suspected
#> 15 toptgn    2018-01-09 2018-01-19   male           suspected
#> 16 syqodd    2018-01-11 2018-01-21   male          not_a_case
#> 17 obxwgw    2018-01-05 2018-01-15 female            probable
#> 18 otjnuo    2018-01-03 2018-01-13 female          not_a_case
#> 19 lkdvdq    2018-01-05 2018-01-15   male          not_a_case
#> 20 zgvabw    2018-01-07 2018-01-17 female           confirmed
#>           messy/dates      lat      lon
#> 1          2018 10 19 11.15835 48.63636
#> 2     // 24//12//1989 13.44349 47.70434
#> 3          2018 10 19 13.29998 50.40891
#> 4          2018-10-18 11.84685 47.10444
#> 5          2018-10-18 13.99547 47.11110
#> 6     // 24//12//1989 10.77559 47.80345
#> 7          2018_10_17 11.87493 46.96751
#> 8     // 24//12//1989 15.98660 47.96508
#> 9          2018-10-18 14.10095 47.73756
#> 10         01-12-2001 16.55314 48.66330
#> 11         2018 10 19 13.29012 48.09566
#> 12 that's 24/12/1989! 12.04832 46.61191
#> 13             female 15.57623 48.21570
#> 14         2018_10_17 10.31869 48.63070
#> 15               <NA> 13.60474 48.23671
#> 16             female 12.97878 47.94264
#> 17         2018-10-18 13.89287 47.09167
#> 18    // 24//12//1989 14.87751 48.76008
#> 19             female 12.16948 47.89376
#> 20 that's 24/12/1989! 13.87396 48.38470

If we have values that are multi-lingual or possibly have typos, we can generate a wordlist that contains two columns, from and to, that will be used to transform any found values in specified columns.

wordlist <- data.frame(
 from  = c("hopsital", "hopital",  "medical", "feild"),
 to    = c("hospital", "hospital", "clinic",  "field"),
 variables = rep("location", 4),
 stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

# location data with mis-spellings, French, and English.
messy_locations <- c("hopsital", "h\u00f4pital", "hospital",
                     "m\u00e9dical", "clinic",
                     "feild", "field")
llsample_spell <- messy_data()
llsample_spell$location <- factor(sample(messy_locations, 20, replace = TRUE))

clean_data(llsample_spell, wordlists = wordlist, spelling_vars = "variables" )
#>        id date_of_onset  discharge gender epi_case_definition       messy_dates
#> 1  kgpyhb    2018-01-03 13_01_2018 female           confirmed        24_12_1989
#> 2  wixgcj    2018-01-09 19_01_2018 female           confirmed        2018_10_18
#> 3  worpik    2018-01-06 16_01_2018   male           suspected            female
#> 4  ofxmah    2018-01-04 14_01_2018   male            probable            female
#> 5  ekqulo    2018-01-08 18_01_2018 female            probable        2018_10_18
#> 6  zdwnbe    2018-01-04 14_01_2018 female           confirmed        2018_10_18
#> 7  fjqmiv    2018-01-08 18_01_2018   male          not_a_case        2018_10_17
#> 8  ljogad    2018-01-04 14_01_2018 female            probable            female
#> 9  bwialr    2018-01-11 21_01_2018 female           confirmed        2018_10_17
#> 10 llxnun    2018-01-11 21_01_2018 female           suspected        24_12_1989
#> 11 qwuwig    2018-01-05 15_01_2018   male          not_a_case that_s_24_12_1989

#> 16 rtyhil    2018-01-07 17_01_2018   male            probable              male
#> 17 howcfc    2018-01-10 20_01_2018   male           confirmed        24_12_1989

Advanced usage

As well as the configurable clean_data() function, many of the capabilities are exposed individually, supporting data pipelines.

llsample_pipe <- ll_sample
llsample_pipe <- clean_dates(llsample_pipe)
llsample_pipe <- clean_variable_names(llsample_pipe)

This gives you highly granular control over the process and is advised when building functions for processing data in your specific usecase / environment.

You can then see the impact of changes by comparing two linelist data.frames.

compare_data(ll_sample, llsample_pipe)
#> 
#>  /// Comparisons of data content // 
#>      (showing differences only)
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of dimensions /
#> Same number of rows and columns
#> 
#>  // Comparison of variable names /
#> 
#>   * variables missing in the new data:
#> [1] "'ID"                 "Date of Onset."      "DisCharge.."        
#> [4] "GENDER_ "            "Épi.Case_définition" "messy/dates"        
#> 
#>   * new variables:
#> [1] "id"                  "date_of_onset"       "discharge"          
#> [4] "gender"              "epi_case_definition" "messy_dates"        
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of variable classes /
#> 
#> 
#>  // Comparison of values in categorical variables /
